title: LC circuit - inductance given charge oscillation

content.question: In an oscillating <math alttext="L C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>LC</mi></math> circuit consisting of an inductor and a capacitor, the charge stored on the capacitor undergoes simple harmonic motion according to the equation <math alttext="Q of t equals, open parenthesis, 3 microcoulombs, close parenthesis, times the sine of open bracket, open parenthesis, 1000 radians per second, close parenthesis, times t, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>Q</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>μC</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1000</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The capacitance of the capacitor is <math alttext="5 microfarads" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>μF</mtext></math>. What is the inductance of the inductor?

topic.text: 13.6: Circuits with Capacitors and Inductors (LC Circuits)

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
